'19','2015-04-07','Best player: Brad Eldred of Florida, who hit 251 minor league home runs from 2002 to 2012 and had four brief stints in the majors, hit 37 homers for the Hiroshima Toyo Carp last year.

Unusual feature: Games still tied after 12 innings end as ties.

Best player: The Venezuelan outfielder Alex Romero, who played two seasons for the Diamondbacks, has been the best player for Rimini for three seasons.

Unusual feature: Italian league teams are the best in Europe, having won the European club championships the last seven times.

Best player: First baseman Park Byung-ho of the Nexen Heroes led the league with 52 home runs (no other player had more than 40) and also had a .433 on-base average.

Unusual feature: The Hanwha Eagles tried to improve their fortunes with cheering robots.

Opening day: The season actually runs fall to spring; the final round of the playoffs is continuing.

Best player: Many top players have defected to the United States, leaving the cupboard fairly bare. Third baseman Yulieski Gourriel, 30, has been one of the greats in Cuba for years.

Unusual feature: Some players are allowed to sign for teams in Japan and elsewhere, but the government takes some of the money from their contracts and they must return for the Cuban season.

Best player: Edwin Alcantara, who moved this season to the Herts Falcons, has been on the championship winner for four straight years. He won the triple crown in 2011, hitting .482 with six homers and 33 runs batted in.

Unusual feature: The regular season is only 24 games.

Best player: Cody Regis, a first baseman who appeared in three College World Series for U.C.L.A., hit .464 last season, enough to get him signed by the Arizona Diamondbacks last month.

Unusual feature: All games are played in weekend doubleheaders.

Oddest nickname: Nothing too strange, but a number of acronyms, including D.S.S., H.C.A.W. and U.V.V.

Best player: Bas De Jong of the Amsterdam Pirates has won the last two M.V.P. Awards.'

'32','2015-04-11','Madison Keys and Lucie Hradecka are surprise semifinalists at the Family Circle Cup in Charleston, S.C. Keys, the seventh seed, beat Lauren Davis, 6-2, 6-2. Hradecka, a qualifier, knocked out the No. 4 seed Sara Errani, 6-2, 6-4. Keys and Hradecka will play Saturday.

Third-seeded Andrea Petkovic, the defending champion, advanced with a 2-6, 6-3, 6-1 victory over the qualifier Danka Kovinic. Petkovic will face fifth-seeded Angelique Kerber, who beat No. 13 seed Irina-Camelia Begu, 7-6 (3), 7-6 (4).'

'33','2015-04-11','United States import prices fell in March as rising petroleum costs were offset by declining prices for other goods, a sign of muted inflation that supports the view the Federal Reserve will probably not raise interest rates in June. The Labor Department said on Friday that import prices dropped 0.3 percent last month after a downwardly revised 0.2 percent gain in February. In the 12 months through March, prices plunged 10.5 percent, the largest drop since September 2009.'

'45','2015-04-15','Children in Sierra Leone returned to school on Tuesday after staying home for nine months because of the Ebola outbreak. More than 8,000 schools were reopening, although attendance at many was poor amid some skepticism that the crisis was over. Unicef helped train 9,000 teachers in Ebola prevention and safety, it said, and is supplying schools with cleaning equipment and 24,300 hand-washing stations. The Ebola outbreak is estimated to have killed 10,587 people, mostly in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone. Liberian schools reopened earlier this year.'

'52','2015-04-17','State Auditor Troy Kelley, the elected official tasked with rooting out government fraud and waste, has been indicted by a federal grand jury on charges of filing false tax returns, attempted obstruction of a civil lawsuit and possession of stolen property. The indictment was unsealed Thursday, alleging misdeeds in connection with mortgage title services companies he previously ran. Federal prosecutors said that he kept more than $1 million that should have been refunded to customers and unlawfully avoided paying taxes by claiming personal or campaign expenses were business-related. The most serious charge carries up to 20 years in prison. Mr. Kelley said he would take a temporary leave of absence beginning May 1. Gov. Jay Inslee, a fellow Democrat, called on him to resign.'

'61','2015-04-21','State officials are projecting that the state will collect $187 million less in taxes through June 2016 than anticipated. The new forecast issued Monday is likely to force Gov. Sam Brownback, a Republican, and the Republican-dominated Legislature to consider larger tax increases than they had expected to balance the state budget. Before the new forecast, they had been working on budget proposals requiring about $150 million a year in tax increases. Revising a forecast made in November, state officials and university economists reduced the estimate for total tax collections for the current fiscal year by nearly $88 million, to about $5.7 billion. They also cut the tax collection estimate for the fiscal year beginning in July by nearly $100 million.'

'73','2015-04-23','A pit bull attacked a police stallion in Brooklyn on Wednesday, biting him on the chest and the leg, the police said.

The horse, Pompey II, 13, was patrolling East New York with Officer Luis Ramos around 12:47 p.m. when the dog charged at them in front of a house at 490 Essex Street. The dog bit Pompey II, causing puncture wounds, but Officer Ramos was able to keep the stallion under control.

Another mounted officer, Laurene Bove, responded on her horse, Limerick, prompting the dog to retreat into its yard.

The dog had been in the yard surrounded by an eight-foot wooden fence and a four-foot chain-link fence, the police said. Investigators believe that when the dog saw Pompey II, it pushed through the wooden fence and jumped the chain-link fence.

The dog was taken to Animal Care and Control, where it will stay until the police finish their inquiry. No charges were filed against the owner Wednesday.

Pompey II was returned to his stable in Brighton Beach, where he was to be treated by a veterinarian. The police said he was expected to make a full recovery. He will be allowed a few days of rest, and will receive a few extra apples and carrots.'

'75','2015-04-24','The United States Treasury on Thursday removed a Burmese businessman from a blacklist that had barred him from doing business in the United States. The man, Win Aung, is president of a business association. The Treasury also removed two companies that he heads from the list. The Obama administration rolled back trade and investment sanctions against Myanmar in 2012 to reward its shift from direct military rule, but the United States still forbids business dealings with military corporations and certain other individuals and companies. Myanmar wants Washington to lift sanctions entirely, but its government has been criticized for stalling on reforms and detaining peaceful protesters.'
